body:
The root cause for that is tracked in: https://github.com/eclipse/hono/issues/932

Yes, it was the client module. And it was in the test source.

However I don't think it is a good idea to compile the main artifact with Java 8, and then compile the test source with Java 11. I also don't think that we should start switching partially to Java 8, as this will immediately introduce the issue of needing different Java toolchains for validating that is still compiles in older versions. As you need to validate against the specific Java API.

I know with OSGi, execution environment, Tycho, this is all not too hard. But for plain Maven, we would need to start setting up each environment (Travis, Jenkins, local machine) with two JDKs.

So I think we should stick to Java 11 overall. Unless there are some reasons that make it absolutely necessary.

The problem we ran into with #932 was not so much an issue of the source/target level but of the JDK being used to compile and run the tests. From a user perspective, I can sympathize with @avgustinmm 's intent to keep compatibility with Java 8 target level because many applications will remain to be built using Java 8 for some time. In fact, Amazon and RedHat are supporting this explicitly by means of continuing to release and support Java 8 level JDKs.
I can imagine simply defining source/target level 1.8 for the core and client modules, thus making sure the resulting artifacts can be used on Java 8 JVMs. We might still be able to configure the Maven build to require a Java 11 JDK in order to mitigate the problem described in #932 ...
I don't think that it would be an issue to have the core/client modules at Java level 1.8 and have the other artifacts at Java 11 level. I also do not see any reason why this would imply having to set up multiple tool chains. FMPOV we could stick with our existing tool chain which uses OpenJDK 11 only.

> I don't think that it would be an issue to have the core/client modules at Java level 1.8 and have the other artifacts at Java 11 level.

What can easily happen is that people use functionality that is not present in the Java 8 APIs. That would result in a Java 8 compiled binary, which fails when being run on Java 8. So the goal of supporting Java 8 would not be accomplished.

I ran into this a few time, typical example was `String.isEmpty()`, which was introduced in Java 6, but people compiled this with Java 6, for Java 5. Resulting in something that passed all tests, and later failed to run in Java 5.

> What can easily happen is that people use functionality that is not present in the Java 8 APIs

This can be prevented by using the *Animal Sniffer* Maven plugin.
I will prepare a corresponding PR. I think it would be worth the effort to keep Java 8 compatibility. After all, we are not using/requiring any Java 11 language features in the core and client modules anyway ...

I am completely agree, that if it would be easy to keep Java 8 compatibility for the client libraries then it should. Java 8 is still here and it will be for some time. So, if there is no technical reason to drop support - better to keep it.
@avgustinmm is it possible for you to check out #1140 and provide some feedback in the PR whether this works for you?

@sophokles73,
I built the PR and tried to install bundles on OSGi & Java 8. I had problems to install them because of manifest header (in both bundles):
  Require-Capability: osgi.ee;filter:="(osgi.ee=UNKNOWN)"
It may be because of a problem with my setup - not sure. However, when I fixed that header the bundles were installed and started successfully.

@avgustinmm 
Hm, I am no OSGi expert. In fact, I have no idea how I can influence the value of this header in the corresponding Maven POM. Do you have any idea what the value should actually be?

I just ran this locally and ended up with (for both client and core):

~~~
Require-Capability: osgi.ee;filter:="(&(osgi.ee=JavaSE)(version=1.8))"
~~~
Yes, it works for me as well. Maybe @avgustinmm can try again to do a full mvn clean install on Hono and see if it works for him as well?

I've built it with clean build but with OpenJDK (I think this might be  important). I just checked https://search.maven.org/artifact/org.eclipse.hono/hono-client/1.0-M1/bundle - the release artifact. It also has: 
Require-Capability: osgi.ee;filter:="(osgi.ee=UNKNOWN)"
while  https://search.maven.org/artifact/org.eclipse.hono/hono-client/0.9/bundle has:
Require-Capability: osgi.ee;filter:="(&(osgi.ee=JavaSE)(version=1.8))"
So, the "unknown" problem is not only with the branch but with 1.0 development. Maybe with change of the build JDK.
@avgustinmm what JDK are you using for building?
